The impact of personal freedom afforded by sanctuary cities on the 2010 undocumented immigrant settlement pattern with the U.S., 2SLS estimates|journal=Journal of Economics and Finance|date=July 28, 2015|volume=40|issue=4|pages=792–802|doi=10.1007/s12197-015-9333-7}}</ref> Concerning health, a study in North Carolina found that after implementation of section 287(g), prenatal Hispanic/Latina mothers were more likely than non-Hispanic/Latina mothers to have late or inadequate prenatal care. The study's interviews indicated that Hispanics/Latinos in the section 287(g) counties had distrust in health services among other services and had fear about going to the doctor.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rhodes|first=Scott D.|last2=Mann|first2=Lilli|last3=Simán|first3=Florence, et al.|year=2015|title=The Impact of Local Immigration Enforcement Policies on the Health of Immigrant Hispanics/Latinos in the United States|url=http://eds.b.ebscohost.com/eds/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?sid=06ecefda-1e96-4091-84d4-0556742fbdcd%40sessionmgr101&vid=1&hid=121|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=105| issue = 2|pages=329–337|via=EBSCOHost|doi=10.2105/ajph.2014.302218|pmc=4318326}}</ref>
=== Laws and policies by state and city ===
==== Alabama ==== * In Alabama, state law ([[Alabama HB 56]]) was enacted in 2011, calling for proactive immigration enforcement; however, many provisions are either blocked by the federal courts or subject to ongoing lawsuits.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} On January 31, 2017, [[William A. Bell]], the mayor of [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]], declared the city a "welcoming city" and said that the police would not be "an enforcement arm of the federal government" with respect to federal immigration law. He also stated that the city would not require proof of citizenship for granting business licenses. The Birmingham City Council subsequently passed a resolution supporting Birmingham being a "sanctuary city".<ref name="BRM">{{cite web|url=http://www.wbrc.com/story/34390802/birmingham-city-council-passes-sanctuary-city-resolution|title=Birmingham City Council passes sanctuary city resolution|first=Mia|last=Watkins|publisher=|accessdate=20 March 2017}}</ref>
==== Arizona ==== * Following the passage of [[Arizona SB 1070]], a state law, few if any cities in Arizona are "sanctuary cities." A provision of SB 1070 requires local authorities to "contact federal immigration authorities if they develop [[reasonable suspicion]] that a person they've detained or arrested is in the country illegally."<ref name="Steller">Tim Steller, [http://tucson.com/news/local/columnists/steller/steller-tucson-a-sanctuary-city-not-so-fast/article_e06cda4e-70f9-56a2-9e86-5b62de2a0933.html Tucson a 'sanctuary city'? Not so fast], ''Arizona Daily Star'' (February 23, 2016).</ref> The [[Center for Immigration Studies]], which advocates restrictive immigration policies, labels only one city in the state, [[South Tucson, Arizona|South Tucson]], a "sanctuary city"; the label is because South Tucson does not honor ICE detainers "unless ICE pays for cost of detention".<ref name="Steller" />
====California==== * According to the [[National Immigration Law Center]], about a dozen California cities have some formal sanctuary policy, and none of the [[List of counties in California|58 California counties]] "complies with detainer requests by [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement]]."<ref name="CarcamoMatherSmith">Cindy Carcamo, Kate Mather & Dakota Smith, [http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-sanctuary-cities-20161114-story.html Trump's crackdown on illegal immigration leaves a lot unanswered for sanctuary cities like L.A.], ''Los Angeles Times'' (November 15, 2016).</ref> * [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]] became the first city in the United States to pass a sanctuary resolution on November 8, 1971.<ref>[http://www.eastbayexpress.com/oakland/berkeley-the-original-sanctuary-city/Content?oid=5306164"Berkeley Is The Original Sanctuary City"] ''East Bay Express'', February 14, 2017. Retrieved March 23, 2017</ref> Additional local governments in certain cities in the United States began designating themselves as sanctuary cities during the 1980s.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mancina|first1=Peter|title=In the Spirit of Sanctuary: Sanctuary City Policy Advocacy and the Production of Sanctuary-Power in San Francisco, California|date=2016|publisher=Vanderbilt University Electronic Theses and Dissertations|location=Nashville|url=http://etd.library.vanderbilt.edu/available/etd-07112016-193322/unrestricted/Mancina.pdf.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Mancina, Peter|editor1-last=Lippert|editor1-first=Randy|editor2-last=Rehaag|editor2-first=Sean|title=Sanctuary Practices in International Perspectives: Migration, Citizenship, and Social Movements|date=2012|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|isbn=978-0-415-67346-4|pages=205–18|url=https://books.google.com/?id=LBAmltBXyUYC&pg=PA205&dq=%22The+Birth+of+a+Sanctuary+City%22#v=onepage&q=%22The%20Birth%20of%20a%20Sanctuary%20City%22&f=false|chapter=The Birth of a Sanctuary City: A History of Governmental Sanctuary in San Francisco}}</ref> Some have questioned the accuracy of the term "sanctuary city" as used in the US.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.americanimmigrationcouncil.org/research/sanctuary-cities-trust-acts-and-community-policing-explained|title="Sanctuary Cities," Trust Acts, and Community Policing Explained|website=American Immigration Council|access-date=2016-10-28}}</ref> The policy was first initiated in 1979 in Los Angeles, to prevent the [[Los Angeles Police Department]] (LAPD) from inquiring about the immigration status of arrestees. Many Californian cities have adopted "sanctuary" [[Local ordinance|ordinances]] banning city employees and [[Public security|public safety]] personnel from asking people about their immigration status.<ref>{{cite news |title=Sanctuary Cities, USA |work=Ohio Jobs & Justice Political Action Committee |publisher=Salvi Communications |url=http://ojjpac.org/sanctuary.asp }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.humanevents.com/article.php?id=20547&c=1&tb=1&pb=1&gd=05042007|title='Sanctuary Cities' Embrace Undocumented Immigrants – Human Events|work=Human Events|accessdate=21 July 2015}}</ref> * [[Coachella, California|Coachella]] - 95% Latino, 2nd highest percentage Latino city in [[Southern California]], adopted the sanctuary policy in 2015. <ref>https://www.desertsun.com/story/news/local/coachella/2017/08/23/coachella-becomes-valleys-second-sanctuary-city/595599001/ </ref> * [[Huntington Beach]] obtain a ruling from the state Supreme Court that the protections in California for immigrants who are in the country illegally do not apply to the 121 [[charter cities]]. The [[Orange County, California|Orange County]] city is the first to successfully challenge SB 54.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-oc-sanctuary-state-20180928-story.html|title=California 'sanctuary' law doesn't apply to charter cities, judge rules in Huntington Beach case |newspaper= [[Los Angeles Times]]|first=Priscella |last=Vega|date=September 28, 2018|access-date=28 September 2018}}</ref> * [[Los Angeles]] – In 1979, the [[Los Angeles City Council]] adopted [[Special Order 40]], barring LAPD officers from initiating contact with a person solely to determine their immigration status.<ref name="MatherChang">Kate Mather & Cindy Chang, [http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-los-angeles-police-immigration-20161114-story.html LAPD will not help deport immigrants under Trump, chief says], ''Los Angeles Times'' (November 14, 2016).</ref> However, the city frequently cooperates with federal immigration authorities.<ref name="CarcamoMatherSmith" /> [[Los Angeles Mayor]] [[Eric Garcetti]] does not use the phrase "sanctuary city" to describe the city because the label is unclear.<ref name="CarcamoMatherSmith" /> * [[San Francisco]] "declared itself a sanctuary city in 1989, and city officials strengthened the stance in 2013 with its 'Due Process for All' ordinance. The law declared local authorities could not hold immigrants for immigration officials if they had no violent felonies on their records and did not currently face charges."<ref name="CarcamoMatherSmith" /> The 2015 [[shooting of Kathryn Steinle]] provoked debate about San Francisco's "sanctuary city" policy.<ref>{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Pearson |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/07/06/us/san-francisco-killing-sanctuary-cities/ |title=What's a sanctuary city, and why should you care? |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=July 8, 2015 |accessdate=26 February 2017}}</ref> * [[Seaside, California|Seaside]] – On March 29, 2017, Seaside became [[Monterey County|Monterey County's]] first sanctuary city.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.montereycountyweekly.com/blogs/news_blog/seaside-becomes-the-monterey-peninsula-s-first-sanctuary-city/article_813739ba-14f1-11e7-a41e-aba3101336dd.html|title=Seaside becomes the Monterey Peninsula's first sanctuary city.|first=David|last=Schmalz|date=|website=MontereyCountyWeekly.com|access-date=October 19, 2017}}</ref> * [[Williams, California|Williams]] - 75% Latino, largest percentage Latino town in [[Northern California]], adopted the policy in 2015. <ref>https://cis.org/Map-Sanctuary-Cities-Counties-and-States</ref> *On October 5, 2017, Governor [[Jerry Brown]] signed a bill, SB 54, that makes California a "sanctuary state". It does not bar local and state agencies from cooperating with ICE regarding certain illegal criminals and ICE can carry out raids targeting undocumented immigrants within the state.<ref>[https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/10/05/555920658/california-governor-signs-sanctuary-state-bill "California Governor Signs 'Sanctuary State' Bill"] [[NPR]]. Retrieved October 5, 2017.</ref>
====Colorado==== * [[Boulder, Colorado|Boulder]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://denver.cbslocal.com/2017/01/04/boulder-city-council-approves-sanctuary-city-status/|title=Boulder City Council Approves Sanctuary City Status|date=4 January 2017|publisher=CBS Denver|accessdate=5 January 2017}}</ref> became a sanctuary city in 2017. * [[Denver]] does not identify as a sanctuary city. The ''Denver Post'' reports: "The city doesn't have an ordinance staking out a claim or barring information-sharing with federal officials about a person's immigration status, unlike some cities. But it is among cities that don't enforce immigration laws or honor federal 'detainer' requests to hold immigrants with suspect legal status in jail past their release dates.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jon Murray|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2017/01/30/mayor-hancock-welcomes-sanctuary-city-title-denver-supports-immigrants-refugees/|title=Mayor Hancock says he welcomes "sanctuary city" title if it means Denver supports immigrants and refugees|newspaper=The Denver Post|date=January 30, 2017}}</ref> * [[Estes Park]] police chief Wes Kufeld stated that, "As far as day-to-day policing, people are not required to provide proof of immigration status, and our officers are not required by ICE to check immigration status, nor to conduct sweeps for undocumented individuals. So, we don’t do these things." He added that town police do assist ICE in the arrest and detainment of any illegal immigrant suspected of a felony.<ref>[https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B8422pzdYDb4SlZnVDYxLUlmajQ "Understanding Immigration Enforcement And The Role Of The Estes Park Police"]. Directed from: [https://www.colorado.gov/pacific/townofestespark/newsdesk Town of Estes Park news, April 21, 2017]. Retrieved July 19, 2017.</ref>
====Connecticut==== {{See also|Elm City Resident Card}} * [[Hartford, Connecticut|Hartford]] passed an ordinance providing services to all residents regardless of their immigration in 2008. Said ordinance also prohibits that police from detaining individuals based solely on their immigration status or inquiring as to their immigration status. In 2016, the ordinance was amended to declare that Hartford is a "Sanctuary City", though the term itself does not have an established legal meaning.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.municode.com/library/ct/hartford/codes/code_of_ordinances?nodeId=PTIIMUCO_CH2AD_ARTXXICISEREIMST|title=Hartford Municipal Code|last=|first=|date=|website=www.municode.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-20}}</ref> * In 2013, Connecticut passed a law that gives local law enforcement officers discretion to carry out immigration detainer requests, though only for suspected felons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ctpost.com/local/article/Connecticut-could-be-in-crosshairs-of-Trump-s-10636358.php|title=Connecticut could be in crosshairs of Trump’s sanctuary city crackdown|publisher=|accessdate=20 March 2017}}</ref> * On February 3, 2017, [[Middletown, CT]] declared itself a sanctuary city. This was in direct response to President Trump's executive order. Said Middletown's mayor, “We don't just take orders from the President of the United States”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wtnh.com/2017/02/03/mayor-declares-middletown-a-sanctuary-city/|title=Mayor declares Middletown a sanctuary city|first=WTNH com|last=Staff|date=3 February 2017|publisher=|accessdate=20 March 2017}}</ref>
====Florida==== * In January 2017 [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade County]] rescinded a policy of insisting the U.S. government pay for detention of persons on a federal list. [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Mayor [[Carlos A. Giménez|Carlos Gimenez]] ordered jails to "fully cooperate" with Presidential immigration policy. He said he did not want to risk losing a larger amount of federal financial aid for not complying. The mayor said Miami-Dade County has never considered itself to be a sanctuary city.<ref name = CNN2>[http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/27/politics/miami-dade-mayor-sanctuary-crackdown/index.html "Florida's largest county to comply with Trump's sanctuary crackdown"], Ray Sanchez, CNN, 27 January 2017.</ref> * St. Petersburg [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] Mayor [[Rick Kriseman]] said residents from all backgrounds implored him to declare a sanctuary city. In February 2017 he blogged that, "I have no hesitation in declaring St. Petersburg a sanctuary from harmful federal immigration laws. We will not expend resources to help enforce such laws, nor will our police officers stop, question or arrest an individual solely on the basis that they may have unlawfully entered the United States." He said the county sheriff’s office has ultimate responsibility for notifying federal officials about people illegally in the city. The mayor criticized President Trump for "demonization of Muslims."<ref>[http://www.baynews9.com/content/news/baynews9/news/article.html/content/news/articles/bn9/2017/2/4/mayor_declares_st_pe.html "Mayor declares St. Petersburg a sanctuary city"] ''Bay News 9'', February 04, 2017. Retrieved February 4, 2017.</ref><ref> [https://medium.com/@Kriseman/shelter-in-the-sunshine-city-8185b50517f4#.a02g47xh0 "Shelter in the Sunshine City"] Rick Kriseman blog. Retrieved February 4, 2017.</ref>
====Georgia==== * The mayor of [[Atlanta, Georgia]] in January 2017 declared the city was a “welcoming city” and “will remain open and welcoming to all”. This statement was in response to President's Trump's executive orders related to “public safety agencies and the communities they serve”. Nonetheless, Atlanta does not consider itself to be a “sanctuary city”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://saportareport.com/trump-enacts-ban-refugees-atlanta-doubles-welcoming-city/|title=As Trump enacts ban on refugees, Atlanta doubles down as a 'welcoming city' – SaportaReport|date=30 January 2017|publisher=|accessdate=20 March 2017}}</ref> Atlanta also has refused to house new [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement|ICE]] detainees in its jail, but will keep the current detainees.
====Illinois==== * [[Chicago]] became a "[[de jure]]" sanctuary city in 2012 when Mayor [[Rahm Emanuel]] and the City Council passed the Welcoming City Ordinance.<ref>Chicago code [https://chicagocode.org/2/2-173/ Welcoming City Ordinance Chapter 2-173], ''chicagocode.org'' (January 25, 2017).</ref><ref>Welcoming City Ordinance [https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/mayor/Office%20of%20New%20Americans/PDFs/WelcomeCityOrdinance.pdf Chapter 2-173 Welcoming City Ordinance], ''City of Chicago'' (January 25, 2017).</ref> The ordinance protects residents' rights to access city services regardless of immigration status and states that Chicago police officers cannot arrest individuals on the basis of immigration status alone.<ref>City of Chicago [https://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/mayor/supp_info/office-of-new-americans/sanctuary-city-supportive-resources.html Sanctuary City Supportive Resources], City of Chicago | Office of New Americans (January 25, 2017).</ref> The status was reaffirmed in 2016.<ref>Mayor's Press Office, [https://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/cdph/provdrs/healthychicago/news/2016/november/mayor-emanuel-reiterates-chicago-s-status-as-sanctuary-city.html Mayor Emanuel Reiterates Chicago's Status as Sanctuary City], ''City of Chicago'' (November 13, 2016).</ref><ref>Richard Gonzales, [https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/11/14/502066703/mayor-rahm-emanuel-chicago-always-will-be-a-sanctuary-city Mayor Rahm Emanuel: 'Chicago Always Will Be A Sanctuary City'] [[NPR]] (November 14, 2016).</ref> * [[Urbana, Illinois]]<ref>Jeff Bossert, [https://will.illinois.edu/news/story/sanctuary-city-measure-passes-urbana-council-on-5-1-vote Sanctuary City Measure Passes Urbana Council On 5–1 Vote] ''WILL Illinois public media news'' (December 20, 2016).</ref> * [[Evanston, Illinois]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/evanston/news/ct-evr-evanston-sanctuary-city-tl-1201-20161129-story.html|title=Evanston strengthens sanctuary city ordinance|last=Bookwalter|first=Genevieve|newspaper=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2017-02-09|language=en-US}}</ref> *On August 28, 2017, Illinois Governor [[Bruce Rauner]] signed a bill into law that prohibited state and local police from arresting anyone solely due to their immigration status or due to federal detainers.<ref name="Bernal2017">{{cite web | last1=Bernal | first1=Rafael | title=Illinois Governor Signs Immigration, Automatic Voter Registration Measures | url=http://thehill.com/latino/348283-illinois-governor-signs-immigration-automatic-voter-registration-measures | date=August 28, 2017 | publisher=''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'' | accessdate=September 9, 2017}}</ref><ref name="GeigerAugust2017">{{cite web | last1=Geiger | first1=Kim | title=Rauner Signs Immigration, Automatic Voter Registration Bills Into Law | url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/politics/ct-bruce-rauner-immigration-voting-met-0829-20170828-story.html | date=August 28, 2017 | publisher=''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' | accessdate=September 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | author1=Runge, Erik | author2=[[Associated Press]] | title=Gov. Rauner Signs Controversial Immigration Bill | url=http://wgntv.com/2017/08/28/watch-live-gov-rauner-to-sign-controversial-immigration-bill/ | date=August 28, 2017 | publisher=[[WGN-TV]] | accessdate=September 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last1=Tareen | first1=Sophia | title=Governor Signs Law Limiting Illinois Police on Immigration | url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/governor-signs-law-limiting-illinois-police-immigration-49472288 | date=August 28, 2017 | publisher=[[ABC News]] (from the [[Associated Press]]) | accessdate=September 9, 2017}}</ref> Some fellow Republicans criticized Rauner for his action, claiming the bill made Illinois a sanctuary state. However, the Illinois associations for Sheriffs and Police Chiefs stated that the bill does not prevent cooperation with the federal government or give sanctuary for illegal immigrants. Both organizations support the bill.<ref>{{cite web | last1=Sfondeles | first1=Tina | title=Right Suggests Rauner Immigration Bill Backing 'Beginning of End' | url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/news/rauner-to-sign-immigration-bill-sparking-anger-on-right/ | date=August 22, 2017 | publisher=''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' | accessdate=September 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last1=Singman | first1=Brooke | title=GOP Gov. Rauner Accused of Making Illinois a 'Sanctuary State' with New Law | url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/08/28/gop-gov-rauner-accused-making-illinois-sanctuary-state-with-new-law.html | date=August 28, 2017 | publisher=[[Fox News]] | accessdate=September 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last1=Schoenburg | first1=Bernard | title=Some In GOP Upset with Rauner Over Immigration Bill | url=http://www.sj-r.com/news/20170904/some-in-gop-upset-with-rauner-over-immigration-bill | date=September 4, 2017 | publisher=''[[The State Journal-Register]]'' | accessdate=September 9, 2017}}</ref>
====Louisiana==== * In [[New Orleans]]<ref name="nola.com">Robert McClendon, [http://www.nola.com/politics/index.ssf/2016/03/sanctuary_city_immigration_new.html 'Sanctuary city' policy puts an end to NOPD's immigration enforcement], ''NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune'' (March 01, 2016).</ref> the [[New Orleans Police Department]] began a new policy to "no longer cooperate with federal immigration enforcement" beginning on Feb. 28, 2016.<ref name="nola.com"/>
====Maine==== * A 2004 executive order prohibited state officials from inquiring about immigration status of individual seeking public assistance, but in 2011, the incoming Maine governor [[Paul LePage]] rescinded this, stating “it is the intent of this administration to promote rather than hinder the enforcement of federal immigration law”. In 2015 Governor LePage accused the city of [[Portland, Maine]] of being a sanctuary city based on the fact that “city employees are prohibited from asking about the immigration status of people seeking city services unless compelled by a court or law”,<ref name=billings>[http://www.pressherald.com/2015/09/15/despite-lepages-remark-sanctuary-city-label-doesnt-fit-portland/ Despite LePage remark, 'sanctuary city' label doesn’t fit Portland, officials say], Randy Billings, September 15, 2015, ''Portland Press Herald''</ref> but Portland city officials did not accept that characterization.<ref name=billings/>
====Maryland==== * In 2008, [[Baltimore, Maryland|Baltimore]] and [[Takoma Park, Maryland|Takoma Park]] are sometimes identified as sanctuary cities.<ref>Laura Schwartzman, [http://www.gazette.net/stories/031908/silvnew202316_32355.shtml Legislation would ban Takoma Park sanctuary policies], Capital News Service (March 19, 2008).</ref> However, "[m]ost local governments in Maryland – including Baltimore – still share information with the federal government."<ref>John Fritze, [http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/politics/bs-md-baltimore-sanctuary-20150723-story.html House passes 'sanctuary city' bill, reigniting immigration debate], ''Baltimore Sun'' (July 23, 2016).</ref> In 2016, Baltimore Mayor [[Stephanie Rawlings-Blake]] said that she did not consider Baltimore to be a "sanctuary city."<ref>Yvonne Wenger, [http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/baltimore-city/politics/bs-md-ci-welcoming-city-20161117-story.html Mayor: Baltimore is a 'welcoming city' for immigrants and refugees], ''Baltimore Sun'' (November 16, 2016).</ref>
====Massachusetts==== * [[Boston]] has an ordinance, enacted in 2014, that bars the [[Boston Police Department]] "from detaining anyone based on their immigration status unless they have a criminal warrant."<ref name="Clauss">Kyle Scott Clauss, [http://www.bostonmagazine.com/news/blog/2016/11/15/boston-sanctuary-city-trust-act/ Boston Already Has Some Sanctuary City Protections: Thanks to the 2014 Trust Act, police can’t detain someone based on their immigration status], ''Boston Magazine'' (November 15, 2016).</ref> [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]], [[Chelsea, Massachusetts|Chelsea]], [[Somerville, Massachusetts|Somerville]], [[Orleans, Massachusetts|Orleans]], [[Northampton, Massachusetts|Northampton]], and [[Springfield, Massachusetts|Springfield]] have similar legislation.<ref name="Clauss" /> In August 2016, Boston Police Commissioner, [[William B. Evans]] re-issued a memo stating “all prisoners who are subject to ICE Detainers must receive equal access to [[Bail in the United States|bail commissioners]], which includes notifying said prisoner of his or her right to seek bail.” Bail commissioners are informed of the person’s status on an ICE detainer list and may set bail accordingly.<ref name="BH1">{{cite web|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/news/local_coverage/2017/01/cops_increasingly_denying_requests_to_hold_illegals|title=Cops increasingly denying requests to hold illegals|publisher=|accessdate=20 March 2017}}</ref> * The [[Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court]] ruled in 2017 that a person cannot be held solely due to an ICE detainer.<ref>http://www.mass.gov/courts/docs/sjc/reporter-of-decisions/new-opinions/12276.pdf</ref>
====Michigan==== * [[Detroit]] and [[Ann Arbor, Michigan|Ann Arbor]] are sometimes referred to as "sanctuary cities" because they "have anti-profiling ordinances that generally prohibit local police from asking about the immigration status of people who are not suspected of any crime."<ref name="Oosting">Jonathan Oosting, [http://www.mlive.com/lansing-news/index.ssf/2015/09/immigrant_advocates_blast_bill.html Push to ban 'sanctuary cities' in Michigan faces criticism from immigrant advocates], MLive (September 30, 2015).</ref> Unlike San Francisco's ordinance, however, the Detroit and Ann Arbor policies do not bar local authorities from cooperating and assisting [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement|ICE]] and [[U.S. Customs and Border Protection|Customs and Border Protection]], and both cities frequently do so. *[[Kalamazoo, Michigan|Kalamazoo]] re-affirmed its status as a sanctuary city in 2017. Vice Mayor Don Cooney stated, "We care about you. We will protect you. We are with you." *[[Lansing, Michigan|Lansing]] voted to become a sanctuary city in April 2017, but reversed the decision a week later due to public and business opposition. An order by mayor [[Virg Bernero]] still prohibits Lansing police officers from asking residents about their immigration status, however. <ref>Lauren Gibbons, {{cite news |url=https://www.mlive.com/news/index.ssf/2017/04/lansing_no_longer_a_sanctuary.html|title=Lansing no longer a sanctuary city|}}, MLive (April 12, 2017)</ref>
====Minnesota==== * [[Minneapolis]] has an ordinance, adopted in 2003,<ref name="Hirsi">Ibrahim Hirsi, [https://www.minnpost.com/politics-policy/2016/11/what-conflict-over-sanctuary-cities-could-mean-twin-cities What the conflict over 'sanctuary cities'could mean for the Twin Cities], ''[[Minn Post]]'' (November 23, 2016).</ref> that directs local law enforcement officers "not to 'take any law enforcement action' for the sole purpose of finding undocumented immigrants, or ask an individual about his or her immigration status."<ref>Mike Mullen, [http://www.citypages.com/news/betsy-hodges-minneapolis-will-remain-a-sanctuary-city-despite-trump-threats/401121615 Betsy Hodges: Minneapolis will remain a 'sanctuary city,' despite Trump threats], ''City Pages'' (November 14, 2016).</ref> The Minneapolis ordinance does not bar cooperation with federal authorities: "The city works cooperatively with the Homeland Security, as it does with all state and federal agencies, but the city does not operate its programs for the purpose of enforcing federal immigration laws. The Homeland Security has the legal authority to enforce immigration laws in the United States, in Minnesota and in the city."<ref name="Hirsi" />
====New York==== * [[Albany, New York|Albany]] - Mayor [[Kathy Sheehan]] stated that the city complies with federal law and cooperates with ICE, but she asserted that comments by national government officials show a failure "to understand what is happening in our cities and why a city like Albany would choose to label itself as a sanctuary city."<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/newshour/show/the-justice-department-is-stepping-up-pressure-on-sanctuary-cities-heres-how-mayors-are-responding "The Justice Department is stepping up pressure on ‘sanctuary cities.’ Here’s how mayors are responding"] PBS Newshour, January 24, 2018. Retrieved January 24, 2018.</ref> * [[Ithaca, New York|Ithaca]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ithacajournal.com/story/news/local/2017/02/01/common-council-approves-sanctuary-city-resolution/97356084/|title=Sanctuary City: Ithaca council approves resolution|last=Weinstein|first=Matt|date=February 1, 2017|work=Ithaca Journal}}</ref> * [[New York City]]<ref>{{citation|title=City Policy Concerning Aliens|url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/records/pdf/executive_orders/1989EO124.PDF|year=1989|via=[[Nyc.gov]]}}</ref> (see also [[illegal immigration to New York City]]) *[[Newburgh, New York]] * [[Rochester, New York|Rochester]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/story/news/2017/01/20/mayor-warren-update-rochesters-sanctuary-city-resolution/96843290/|title=Mayor Warren to update Rochester's sanctuary city resolution|first=James|last=Goodman|date=20 January 2017|work=Rochester Democrat and Chronicle}}</ref> * [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]]<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://wrvo.org/post/final-state-city-speech-miner-declares-syracuse-sanctuary-city|title=In final State of the City speech, Miner declares Syracuse a sanctuary city|publisher=[[WRVO|WRVO Public Media]]|date=13 January 2017|accessdate=13 January 2017}}</ref>
====New Jersey==== Among the municipalities which are considered sanctuary cities are Asbury Park, Camden, East Orange, Hoboken, Jersey City, Linden, New Brunswick, Newark, North Bergen, Plainfield, Trenton and Union City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nj1015.com/what-towns-in-new-jersey-are-considered-sanctuary-cities/?trackback=tsmclip|title=What towns in New Jersey are considered sanctuary cities?|author=|date=|website=New Jersey 101.5 – New Jersey News Radio|access-date=October 19, 2017}}</ref> Those with specific executive orders made by mayors or resolution by municipal councils are: * [[Jersey City, New Jersey|Jersey City]]<ref name="twsNJcom2016Nov">Terrence T. McDonald, The Jersey Journal, November 23, 2016, (via) nj.com, [http://www.nj.com/hudson/index.ssf/2016/11/jersey_city_will_protect_immigrants_from_hate_and.html Jersey City will protect immigrants from 'hate and prejudice,' councilman says], Retrieved November 24, 2016</ref><ref name=twsNJcomFeb>Terrence T. McDonald, The Jersey Journal, NJ.com, February 2, 2017, [http://www.nj.com/hudson/index.ssf/2017/02/fulop_says_he_will_make_jersey_city_a_sanctuary_ci.html Fulop says he will sign order making Jersey City a true 'sanctuary city'], Retrieved February 4, 2017</ref> * [[Maplewood, New Jersey|Maplewood]]<ref name="twsNJcom2017Jan">Eric Kiefer, NJ Patch, January 20, 2017, (via) patch.com, [http://patch.com/new-jersey/maplewood/maplewood-1st-n-j-town-offer-immigrants-sanctuary-2017 Maplewood 1st N.J. Town To Offer Immigrants ‘Sanctuary’ In 2017], Retrieved January 20, 2017</ref> * [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mazzola|first1=Jessica|title=Why these 5 N.J. 'sanctuary' communities could be targeted by Trump|url=http://www.nj.com/essex/index.ssf/2017/01/where_are_njs_sanctuary_cities_and_how_will_trump.html|website=NJ.com|accessdate=28 March 2017|ref=njcom2017jan}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.com/essex/index.ssf/2017/06/newark_mayor_signs_sanctuary_city_executive_order.html|title=Newark mayor signs sweeping sanctuary city executive order|author=|date=June 2017|website=NJ.com|access-date=October 19, 2017}}</ref> * [[East Orange, New Jersey|East Orange]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vereau|first1=Gery|title= Orange Approves Sanctuary City Resolution|url=https://voicesofny.org/2017/01/east-orange-approves-sanctuary-city-resolution/|website=voicesofny.org|accessdate=28 March 2017|ref=jessmsc}}</ref> * [[Prospect Park, New Jersey|Prospect Park]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://observer.com/2017/02/prospect-park-mayor-mohamed-khairullah-wins-kudos-for-sanctuary-city-exec-order/|title=Prospect Park Mayor Mohamed Khairullah Wins Kudos for Sanctuary City Exec Order|author=|date=6 February 2017|website=Observer.com|access-date=October 19, 2017}}</ref> * [[Union City, New Jersey|Union City]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hudsonreporter.com/view/full_story/27367513/article-Union-City-becomes-a-sanctuary-city--Commissioners-vote-for-designation-|title=Union City becomes a sanctuary city Commissioners vote for designation{{snd}}Union City has become the second municipality in Hudson County (after Jersey City) to designate itself a sanctuary city in the wake of Donald Trump’s executive order pressuri...|publisher=}}</ref> *[[Highland Park, New Jersey|Highland Park]] (see:[[Reformed Church of Highland Park]]) *[[Hoboken, New Jersey|Hoboken]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://patch.com/new-jersey/hoboken/hoboken-declared-fair-welcoming-city-support-immigrants|title=Hoboken Declared 'Fair And Welcoming City' To Support Immigrants|date=2018-01-02|work=Hoboken, NJ Patch|access-date=2018-06-21|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hobokennj.gov/docs/mayor/Bhalla-EO1-Fair-Welcoming-City.pdf|title=Executive Order Declaring Hoboken a Fair and Welcoming City|last=Bhalla|first=Ravi|date=1 January 2018|website=HobokenNJ.gov|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180621143624/http://hobokennj.gov/docs/mayor/Bhalla-EO1-Fair-Welcoming-City.pdf|archivedate=2018-06-21|dead-url=yes|accessdate=21 June 2018}}</ref>
==== North Carolina ==== * The state of [[North Carolina]] currently restricts any city or municipality from refusing to cooperate with federal immigration and customs enforcement officials.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/news/politics-government/state-politics/article131526634.html|title=NC House bill would penalize immigration sanctuary cities|work=newsobserver|access-date=2017-03-25|language=en}}</ref> There are therefore no official sanctuary cities in the state. A bill, under consideration as of March 2017, is entitled Citizens Protection Act of 2017 or HB 63. Under the new provisions, the state would be able to deny bail to undocumented immigrants for whom Immigration and Customs Enforcements (ICE) has issued a detainer; allow the state to withhold tax revenues from cities who are not in compliance with the statewide immigration regulations; and encourage tipsters to identify municipalities which violate these laws.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.aclu.org/news/nc-house-committee-advances-anti-immigrant-measure|title=N.C. House Committee Advances Anti-Immigrant Measure|work=American Civil Liberties Union|access-date=2017-03-25|language=en}}</ref>
==== Ohio ==== * [[Cincinnati]]'s mayor declared the city a sanctuary city on January 30, 2017 in response to a [[Executive Order 13769|federal executive order limiting immigration]] issued three days earlier.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/politics/2017/01/30/cranley-announce-cincinnati-sanctuary-city/97240174/|title=Cincinnati now a 'sanctuary city.' What's that mean?|newspaper=Cincinnati.com|language=en|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref>
====Oregon==== * State law passed in 1987: "Oregon Revised Statute 181.850, which prohibits law enforcement officers at the state, county or municipal level from enforcing federal immigration laws that target people based on their race or ethnic origin, when those individuals are not suspected of any criminal activities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pamplinmedia.com/ht/118-hillsboro-tribune-opinion/336925-216159-our-opinion-sanctuary-cities-not-controversial-in-oregon-history|title=Our Opinion: 'Sanctuary' cities not controversial in Oregon history|publisher=|accessdate=20 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.opb.org/news/article/immigrant-sanctuary-oregon-law-repeal/|title=Potential Oregon Ballot Measure Targets 'Sanctuary' Immigration Law|last=Wilson|first=Conrad|date=December 6, 2016|work=Oregon Public Broadcasting}}</ref> * [[Beaverton, Oregon|Beaverton]] city council passed a resolution in January 2017 stating, in part, "The City of Beaverton is committed to living its values as a welcoming city for all individuals ...regardless of a person's ... immigration status" and that they would abide by Oregon state law of not enforcing federal immigration laws.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pamplinmedia.com/bvt/339871-219990-beaverton-becomes-sanctuary-city|title=Beaverton becomes sanctuary city|publisher=|accessdate=20 March 2017}}</ref> * [[Corvallis, Oregon|Corvallis]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.opb.org/news/article/corvallis-declares-itself-sanctuary-city/|title=Corvallis Declares Itself Sanctuary City|last=Wilson|first=Conrad|date=December 13, 2016|work=Oregon Public Broadcasting}}</ref> * [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kgw.com/news/investigations/what-is-a-sanctuary-city-and-what-does-it-mean-in-portland/362144981|title=What is a sanctuary city and what does it mean in Portland?|first=|last=TEGNA|publisher=|accessdate=20 March 2017}}</ref> ====Pennsylvania==== There are currently 18 sanctuary jurisdictions in the state of [[Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Copeland|first1=Rich|title=PA's Sanctuary Cities|url=http://www.witf.org/smart-talk/2017/03/pas-sanctuary-cities-a-showdown-at-atlantic-sunrise.php|website=www.Witf.org}}</ref><ref name="Map of Sanctuary Cities">{{cite web|title=Sanctuary City Map|url=https://cis.org/Map-Sanctuary-Cities-Counties-and-States|website=Center for Immigration Studies}}</ref> Sanctuary jurisdictions exist in [[Bradford County, Pennsylvania|Bradford County]], [[Bucks County, Pennsylvania|Bucks County]], [[Chester County, Pennsylvania|Chester County]], [[Clarion County, Pennsylvania|Clarion County]], [[Delaware County, Pennsylvania|Delaware County]], [[Erie County, Pennsylvania|Erie County]], [[Franklin County, Pennsylvania|Franklin County]], [[Lebanon County, Pennsylvania|Lebanon County]], [[Lehigh County, Pennsylvania|Lehigh County]], [[Lycoming County, Pennsylvania|Lycoming County]], [[Montgomery County, Pennsylvania|Montgomery County]], [[Montour County, Pennsylvania|Montour County]], [[Perry County, Pennsylvania|Perry County]], [[Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia County]], [[Pike County, Pennsylvania|Pike County]], and [[Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania|Westmoreland County]].
[[Philadelphia]] mayor [[Jim Kenney]] said in November 2016 that federal immigration policies lead to more crime, and that crime rates declined the year he reinstated a sanctuary city policy.<ref name="Philadelphia stays a 'sanctuary city' despite Trump">{{cite news|last1=Terruso|first1=Julia|title=Kenney: Philadelphia stays a 'sanctuary city' despite Trump|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/news/politics/20161111_Kenney__Philadelphia_stays_a__sanctuary_city__despite_Trump.html|publisher=The Inquirer}}</ref> U.S. Attorney General Sessions has included Philadelphia on the list of cities threatened with subpoenas if they fail to provide documents to show whether local law enforcement officers are sharing information with federal immigration authorities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/justice-department-threatens-to-subpoena-records-in-escalating-battle-with-sanctuary-jurisdictions/2018/01/24/984d0fee-0113-11e8-bb03-722769454f82_story.html|title=Justice Department threatens to subpoena records in escalating battle with ‘sanctuary’ jurisdictions|last=Zapotosky|first=Matt|date=2018-01-24|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-04-18|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
====Washington==== * [[Seattle]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/seattle-will-remain-sanctuary-city-for-immigrants-despite-trump-presidency-mayor-says/|title=Seattle will remain sanctuary city for immigrants despite Trump presidency, mayor says|website=Seattle Times}}, Retrieved January 23, 2017</ref>
==Canada==
===Ontario === [[Toronto]] was the first city in [[Canada]] to declare itself a sanctuary city, with [[Toronto City Council]] voting 37–3 on February 22, 2013 to adopt a formal policy allowing undocumented migrants to access city services.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Keung|first1=Nicholas|title=Toronto declared ‘sanctuary city’ to non-status migrants|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2013/02/21/cisanctuarycity21.html|accessdate=February 13, 2017|work=Toronto Star|date=February 22, 2013}}</ref> [[Hamilton, Ontario]] declared itself a sanctuary city in February 2014 after the [[Hamilton, Ontario City Council|Hamilton City Council]] voted unanimously to allow undocumented immigrants to access city-funded services such as shelters, housing and food banks.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.thespec.com/news-story/4364479-hamilton-to-become-sanctuary-city-for-newcomers-who-fear-deportation/| title=Hamilton to become ‘sanctuary city’ for newcomers who fear deportation|last=Van Dongen| first=Matthew| date=February 12, 2014| work=The Hamilton Spectator}}</ref> In response to US President [[Donald Trump]]'s [[Executive Order 13769]], the [[London City Council|city council]] of [[London, Ontario]] voted unanimously to declare London a sanctuary city in January 2017<ref>{{cite news|last1=Maloney|first1=Patrick|title=London, Ont. unanimously backs call to declare itself a sanctuary city against Trump|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/london-ont-unanimously-backs-call-to-declare-itself-a-sanctuary-city-against-trump|accessdate=February 13, 2017|work=National Post|agency=Postmedia News|date=January 31, 2017}}</ref> with [[Montreal]] doing the same in February 2017 after a unanimous vote.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Shingler|first1=Benjamin|title=Montreal becomes 'sanctuary city' after unanimous vote|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/montreal-sanctuary-city-1.3990835|accessdate=February 13, 2017|work=CBC News|agency=CBC|date=February 20, 2017}}</ref>
===Western Canada===
While [[Vancouver]], [[Canada]] is not a sanctuary city, it adopted an "Access to City Services without Fear" policy for residents that are undocumented or have an uncertain immigration status in April 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fisher|first1=Gavin|title=Vancouver approves 'Access Without Fear' policy for undocumented immigrants|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/vancouver-approves-access-without-fear-policy-for-undocumented-immigrants-1.3523962|accessdate=February 13, 2017|work=CBC News|date=April 7, 2016}}</ref> The policy does not apply to municipal services operated by individual boards, including services provided by the [[Vancouver Police Department]], [[Vancouver Public Library]], or [[Vancouver Park Board]].<ref name="tc refugees feb 2017">{{cite news|last1=Lindsay|first1=Bethany|last2=Eagland|first2=Nick|title=Fearing U.S. crackdown, refugees run to B.C.|url=http://www.timescolonist.com/news/local/fearing-u-s-crackdown-refugees-run-to-b-c-1.9824653|accessdate=February 13, 2017|work=Times Colonist|date=February 11, 2017|location=Victoria, BC}}</ref>
{{As of|February 2017}}, the cities of [[Calgary]], [[Ottawa]], [[Regina, Saskatchewan|Regina]], [[Saskatoon]], and [[Winnipeg]] are considering motions to declare themselves sanctuary cities.<ref name="tc refugees feb 2017" /><ref>{{cite news|last1=Pike|first1=Helen|title=Nenshi looking for more information on implications of becoming a 'sanctuary city'|url=http://www.metronews.ca/news/calgary/2017/02/28/nenshi-not-pitching-calgary-sanctuary-city-without-more-info.html|accessdate=March 30, 2017|work=Metro Calgary|date=February 28, 2017|language=en}}</ref>
{{As of|2018|9|9|df=US}}, [[Edmonton]] adopted "Access Without Fear" policy for undocumented and vulnerable residents.
==United Kingdom== In the [[United Kingdom]], sanctuary cities provide services – such as housing, education, and cultural integration – to [[asylum seekers]] (i.e. persons fleeing one country and seeking protection in another).<ref name="theguardian.com"/> The movement began in [[Sheffield]] in the north of [[England]] in 2005. It was motivated by a national policy adopted in 1999 to disperse asylum seekers to different towns and cities in the UK.
===Sheffield===
In 2009, the city council of [[Sheffield, UK]] drew up a manifesto outlining key areas of concern and 100 supporting organizations signed on.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fmreview.org/sites/fmr/files/FMRdownloads/en/urban-displacement/darling-barnet-eldridge.pdf|title=John Darling, Craig Barnett, Sarah Eldridge "City of Sanctuary – a UK initiative for hospitality", Forced Migration Review, 9 October 2016|author=|date=|website=FMReview.org|access-date=20 October 2017}}</ref>
A city's status as a place of sanctuary is not necessarily a formal governmental designation. The organization [[City of Sanctuary (UK)|City of Sanctuary]] encourages local grassroots groups throughout the UK and Ireland to build a culture of hospitality towards asylum seekers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cityofsanctuary.org/about/|title=About City of Sanctuary|publisher=|access-date=20 March 2017}}</ref>
===Glasgow=== [[Glasgow]] is a noted sanctuary city in [[Scotland]]. In 2000 the city council accepted their first asylum seekers relocated by the [[Home Office]]. The Home Office provided funding to support asylum seekers but would also forcibly deport them ("removal seizures") if it was determined they could not stay in the UK. As of 2010 Glasgow had accepted 22,000 asylum seekers from 75 different nations. In 2007, local residents upset by the human impact of removal seizures, organized watches to warn asylum seekers when Home Office vans were in the neighborhood. They also organized protests and vigils which led to the ending of the removal seizures.<ref name="eveningtimes.co.uk"/><ref name="adamtomforrest.com"/>
== See also == {{Portal|United States|Law}} * [[Kentucky and Virginia Resolutions]] * [[Rapid response team (resistance movement)|Rapid response team]] * [[Safe-haven law]] * [[Sanctuary movement]] * [[Sanctuary campus]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book|editor1= James Ciment |editor2=John Radzilowski|title=American Immigration: An Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PPFnBwAAQBAJ|year= 2014 |edition=2nd |publisher=[[M. E. Sharpe]] |isbn=9780765682130 |chapter=Local governments and immigration |author=Laura Lopez-Sanders }} * [https://www.americanimmigrationcouncil.org/research/sanctuary-policies-overview American Immigration Council: “Sanctuary” Policies: An Overview]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2014}} '''''Thacker, Spink & Co.''''' was a well-known [[Kolkata]] publishing company. ''Thacker's Bengal Directory'' was published from 1864 to 1884 and covered the [[Bengal Presidency]] – which included the present day [[Myanmar]] and [[Bangladesh]]. From 1885 the ''Directory'' covered the whole of [[British India]] and was renamed '''''Thacker's Indian Directory'''''. It was later owned by [[Kameshwar Singh|Maharaja of Darbhanga]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Appendices|date=1982|publisher=India. Second Press Commissior Controller of Publications|pages=266, 343|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tBwuAAAAMAAJ&q=darbhanga+Thacker+Spink&dq=darbhanga+Thacker+Spink&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Ul0sU5_BH46zrgfjsoCYBw&ved=0CEkQ6AEwBQ}}</ref> It continued to be published until 1960.
The directory was essentially an [[almanac]] which listed British and Foreign Merchants and Manufacturers, Commercial Industries, Army, railway and government departments and office holders, European residents, and separately, prominent non-European residents. Earlier editions of ''Thacker'' had street directories of major cities, such as Kolkata and [[Yangon]], together with the name of the residents of each house.
Similar directories published included: *''Thacker's Bombay Directory'', city and island (together with a directory of the chief industries of Bombay, etc.); *Thacker's medical directory of India, Burma and Ceylon; *''Thacker's Directory of the Chief Industries of India, Burma and Ceylon''.

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = The Penguin Guide to Jazz | title_orig = The Penguin Guide to Jazz on CD, LP and Cassette | translator = | image = PenguinGuidetoJazz8th.jpg | caption = The cover of the 8th edition of the ''Penguin Guide to Jazz'', with a photograph of [[Philly Joe Jones]] by [[Francis Wolff]], Nola Rehearsal Studio, [[New York City|NYC]], 1959. | author = [[Richard Cook (journalist)|Richard Cook]]
[[Brian Morton (Scottish writer)|Brian Morton]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[United Kingdom]] | language = English | series = Penguin Guide | subject = [[Jazz]] | genre = [[Non-fiction]]
[[Encyclopedia|Encyclopedic]]
[[Reference]] | publisher = [[Penguin Books]] | release_date = 1992 | media_type = [[Paperback]] | pages = 1312 | isbn = 978-0-14-015364-4 | oclc= 468362981 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Penguin Guide to Jazz''''' is a [[reference work]] containing an [[encyclopedic]] directory of [[jazz]] recordings on [[compact disc|CD]] which are currently available in Europe or the United States. The first nine editions were compiled by [[Richard Cook (journalist)|Richard Cook]] and [[Brian Morton (Scottish writer)|Brian Morton]], two well known chroniclers of jazz resident in the United Kingdom. == History == The first edition was published in [[United Kingdom|Britain]] by [[Penguin Books]] in 1992. Every two years since then, through 2010, a new edition has been published with updated entries. The eighth and ninth editions, published in 2006 and 2008, respectively, each include 2,000 new CD listings. The title has taken different forms over the lifetime of the work, as audio technology has changed. The seventh edition was known as ''The Penguin Guide to Jazz on CD'' while subsequent editions are titled ''The Penguin Guide to Jazz Recordings.'' The earliest edition had the title ''The Penguin Guide to Jazz on CD, LP and Cassette''.{{cite web | title=The Penguin guide to jazz on CD, LP and cassette : a comprehensive, critical guide to recorded jazz : from its beginnings until the present | url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/penguin-guide-to-jazz-on-cd-lp-and-cassette-a-comprehensive-critical-guide-to-recorded-jazz-from-its-beginnings-until-the-present/oclc/243780266?referer=di&ht=edition | work=[[WorldCat]] | accessdate=2011-02-01 }} Richard Cook died in 2007, prior to the completion of the 9th edition (2008).{{Cite news | last=Morton | first=Brian | title=Richard Cook | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/richard-cook-401071.html | newspaper=[[The Independent]] | date=2007-09-01 | accessdate=2011-02-01 }}{{Cite news | last=Kerr | first=Alison | title= Brian Morton and Richard Cook, eds: The Penguin Jazz Guide (Penguin) | url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/arts-ents/non-fiction-reviews/brian-morton-and-richard-cook-eds-the-penguin-jazz-guide-penguin-1.1065163 | newspaper=[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]] | date=2010-11-01 | accessdate=2011-02-01 }} Penguin released ''The Penguin Jazz Guide: The History of the Music in the 1001 Best Albums'' in December 2010, using fewer reviews and a different format from previous editions.{{cite web | title=The Penguin Jazz Guide | url=http://us.penguingroup.com/nf/Book/BookDisplay/0,,9780141048314,00.html | work=Penguin.com (USA) | accessdate=2011-02-01 }} == Content == In the first nine editions, artists are listed alphabetically and the entries begin with short (usually one paragraph) [[biographies]] before a comprehensive listing of a musicians' available [[discography|recordings]]. Each disc is given a rating of up to four stars and details of its label and catalogue number, musicians featured on the disc, month and year of the recording or the span of time in which the tracks were recorded and finally a review of varying length. Often a number of discs are reviewed together. Two extra features, author's picks (crowns) and "core collections", have been added to succeeding editions. The first shows entries flagged as personal favorites while the latter are the "more essential" albums for a jazz CD collection. John Eyles comments in a review that "the implication is that the choices for crowns are subjective, while the Core Collection is somehow more objective," when in fact both lists are decided upon by the same two editors.{{cite web|url=http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/article.php?id=23610|title=The Penguin Guide To Jazz Recordings, 8th Edition|author=John Eyles|accessdate=2006-04-18}} Bootlegs and limited-edition [[Mosaic Records]] releases are excluded. Various-artists compilations were reviewed in the first edition but were dropped in later editions. Due to the increasing numbers of CDs on the market, space limitations and depth of coverage have increasingly become an issue: in the 7th edition, for instance, the index was dropped to save space, but it was restored in the 8th edition (but a number of entries were dropped or shortened to make room for it). In the tenth edition, titled ''The Penguin Jazz Guide'' (2010), Morton revised his and Cook's entries from previous editions, and pared down the content to 1001 reviews of what Morton had selected as the best jazz recordings. Morton also presented the reviews in chronological order by recording dates, rather than alphabetically by artist, and included historical context for the recordings as well as biographical details. The tenth edition also dispensed with the starred rating system, the Core Collection, and Crown accolades.{{cite book|last = Morton|first = Brian|authorlink = Brian Morton (Scottish writer)|author2=Richard Cook |authorlink2=Richard Cook (journalist) |title = The Penguin Jazz Guide: The History of the Music in the 1001 Best Albums |origyear = 1992|edition = 10th | series = The Penguin Guide to Jazz|year = 2010|publisher = Penguin|location = New York|isbn = 978-0-14-104831-4|pages = xxix-xxx}} == Reception == Though the first nine editions did not "spring any great surprises," the book "has a tried and trusted formula that works". It is also praised as being "of equal value to both experienced jazz listeners and novices." Alison Kerr, reviewing the 2010 ''Penguin Jazz Guide'' in ''[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]'', noted the lack of an index as a hindrance, but cited the chronological format as one of the book's strengths. Kerr also noted the subjective nature of Morton's selection of the best jazz albums. == Editions == {| |- style="text-align:center; background:#f0f0f0;" ||'''Edition''' ||'''Title''' ||'''Year''' ||'''ISBN''' |- | 1st||''The Penguin Guide to Jazz on CD, LP and Cassette''||1992||{{ISBNT|9780140153644}} |- | 2nd||''The Penguin Guide to Jazz on CD, LP and Cassette''||1994||{{ISBNT|9780670858163}} |- | 3rd||''The Penguin Guide to Jazz on CD''||1996||{{ISBNT|9780140513684}} |- | 4th||''The Penguin Guide to Jazz on CD''||1998||{{ISBNT|9780140513837}} |- | 5th||''The Penguin Guide to Jazz on CD''||2000||{{ISBNT|9780140514520}} |- | 6th||''The Penguin Guide to Jazz on CD''||2002||{{ISBNT|9780140515213}} |- | 7th||''The Penguin Guide to Jazz on CD''||2004||{{ISBNT|9780141014166}} |- | 8th||''The Penguin Guide to Jazz Recordings''||2006||{{ISBNT|9780141023274}} |- | 9th||''The Penguin Guide to Jazz Recordings''||2008||{{ISBNT|9780141034010}} |- | 10th||''The Penguin Jazz Guide''||2010||{{ISBNT|9780141048314}} |- | |} == See also == * ''[[All Music Guide to Jazz]]'' * ''[[The Rolling Stone Jazz Record Guide]]'' ==References== {{DEFAULTSORT:Penguin Guide to Jazz, The}} [[Category:Encyclopedias of music]] [[Category:Jazz books]] [[Category:Music guides]] [[Category:Penguin Books books]]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} The '''''Tongdian''''' ({{zh|c=通典|w='''T'ung-tien'''|l=Comprehensive Institutions}}) is a Chinese institutional history and encyclopedia text. It covers a panoply of topics from high antiquity through the year 756, whereas a quarter of the book focuses on the [[Tang Dynasty]]. The book was written by [[Du You]] from 766 to 801. It contains 200 volumes and about 1.7 million words, and is at times regarded as the most representative contemporary texts of the Tang Dynasty. Du You also incorporated many materials from other sources, including a book written by his nephew, [[Du Huan]], who was taken captive in the famous battle at the [[Battle of Talas|Talas River]] between Tang and the Arabs in 751 and did not return to [[China]] until ten years later. It became a model for works by scholar [[Zheng Qiao]] and [[Ma Duanlin]] centuries later.<ref>Zhang Xiuping et al., ''100 Books That Influenced China'', p.232-237</ref>
[[Robert G. Hoyland]] relates that the ''Tongdian'' 's first draft was a "history of human institutions from earliest times down to the reign of [[Emperor Xuanzong of Tang]]", and was subsequently revised as matters continued to evolve.<ref>Hoyland, ''Seeing Islam as Others Saw It'', p. 244</ref> It incorporates parts of the ''[[Zhengdian (book)|Zhengdian]]'' of [[Liu Zhi (historian)|Liu Zhi]] and the ''Great Tang Ritual Regulations of the Kaiyuan Era'' compiled by Xiao Song, and others in 732.<ref>Twitchett, ''Official History under the T'ang'', 104-7</ref> The ''Tongdian'' was never included in the canon of the ''[[Twenty-Four Histories]].'' It was however quoted extensively in several books which were, starting with the ''[[Old Book of Tang]].''
== Content == # 食貨典 Food and commodity # 選舉典 Examination and advancement # 職官典 Government offices # 禮典 Rites # 樂典 Music # 兵典 Military # 刑法典 Penal law # 州郡典 Local administration # 邊防典 Border defense
== Notes == {{reflist}}

''[[Encyclopedia of China]]'', 1st ed. *[http://www.chinaknowledge.de/Literature/Science/tongdian.html Tongdian 通典 "Comprehensive Statutes"] *[http://zh.wikisource.org/wiki/%E9%80%9A%E5%85%B8 通典 Full text in Chinese]
